what do we want to do with these kind of errors: <https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/job/fabric-verify-x86_64/914/console>
those test resources seem to be problematic as they are used by multiple branches and pending Gerrit changesets that need different settings
what do you mean by settings?

I mean that main and feature/convergence need different chaincode interfaces to be implemented in the test code so only one of them will work. on the other side, if you upload a new gerrit changeset, and change something related to that test you will have to create a PR to the Github of fabric-resources and 1) if that is merged your changeset will pass the tests but master and feature will most probably fail 2) your changeset will fail the tests
oh
people usually work this around by having forks of fabric resources but that leads to source pointing to non-official repos
yea that test isn't good
we should somehow find ways to permanently fix that
any ideas?
not fetch from http?

<@U0XR6J961>  - the test that fails is actually the one which tests the ability to deploy chaincode from a remote repository so unfortunately not fetching from http is not an option for this particular test.   

(BTW - <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/901/>  puts in a temporary fix for this on the master branch - basically points master at a different remote repo for the chaincode)

The fact that these tests are failing is actually good IMHO because (and I know I sound like a broken record) we have got to find a way to version packages / interfaces for different releases of the fabric.
well, fetch from a locally created http server
if you take a look at the "fix" I attempted, the idea was that we could use something like <http://gopkg.in|gopkg.in> in conjunction with branching / tagging
<@U0XR6J961> - possible but that server would need to implement the github metadata
i never found that interface useful tho
you should ship your own code
not have the server fetch it from somewhere
"go get" only supports specific remote locations and they are all source code control systems - so a straight http download does not work
you're not guaranteed that the server will actually produce the same files
why do we need to test whether go get can fetch from http?
the other option for chaincode specifically is that we move to a model where you always vendor the dependencies
or from git
we know that it can

We are testing the end to end deployment of chaincode from a remote repository - I think the test is valid if we are going to support the functionality.  Personally, I think we can (and should) remove deployment of chaincode from remote repositories in v1 since we now have the SDK which can deploy chaincode from your local system
yes, i agree
BUT - it still does not solve the problem of breaking interfaces across releases.  We need a strategy for properly packaging and versioning the chaincode package

Go 1.7 offers the ability (its experimental) to actually ship packages as binaries - that might be interesting to look at as well when it comes to creating a proper SDK/package for developing chaincode
i think the shim needs to be broken out and versioned
<@U0PB67X4K> where is your fix attempt?
I like the idea of this versioning
it has been merged already on master  --   <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/901/>

<@U14DA4NAD|jchenibm> has joined the channel
how exactly will we use this? when should one increase the version number?

<@U1AU8DRQR> - in many ways that is the question of the hour.  Here's my take / proposal:

1) We actually need to start cutting releases - I propose we have release branches (perhaps we can also use tags as well)

2) Each time we cut a release branch we increment the version of the master branch

3) Currently it looks like "version" is set via an environment variable in the Makefile (which will work) but perhaps if we have a coordinated version strategy we can actually at least put the major version in the metadata package
BUT - we have an issue with the convergence branch right now - what version to give it?
on the other hand, we could start to version individual packages as well if we can get a proper package / module structure in place for v1
in any case, this topic needs some serious thought and discussion ASAP

<@U0PB67X4K> okay so lets suppose we use versions you described. but what if I work on master and I want to create a new change which breaks the test and I also want to fix the test in that change such that the test passes

I think introducing breaking changes on master is ok (of course as you mention we need to fix / update the tests) once we actually get a stable version strategy in place.   Once we have "stable" releases (or simply releases) we can point folks who simply want to build fabric applications to those release versions.   If you want to live on the bleeding edge and use the "master" version of the fabric, you'll simply need to keep up with changes
so as long as we have say fabric v0.6 and a chaincode shim package v0.6 (the main external culprit), we'll be ok.  We can version our samples, interfaces, etc
do you mean that it OK if a change intentionally breaks that test on master and then another change in fabric-test-resouces fixes it?
this will take some planning and coordination, but is certainly doable
<@U1AU8DRQR> - yes
with the assumption that we properly version fabric-test-resources as well

wouldn't there be a solution where master could go from a clean state to a clean state? one where while developing the change in Gerrit master would be okay, and the change in Gerrit would also pass the tests and after merging the change master would also pass the tests?
Definitely
you mean there is one?

with your solution, I think the following would happen:
- I upload a change to Gerrit that breaks the test
- master works because it downloads the test files from some proper version. OK
- my change fails because it needs a modified version of the tests. what should I do? if I modify the current version that breaks master. if I don't that makes my change fail the Jenkins tests
<@U1AU8DRQR>  - are you talking specifically about this clash we currently have with the convergence branch not really having a version?

an alternative to what I did in 901 would have been to use a separate repo for the external chaincode for the convergence branch until such time as it becomes master.  The same would hold true for feature branches

<@U0PB67X4K> : no, I am talking about the situation when one wants to create a change on master (in Gerrit) and wants the test to pass (e.g. they need to be changed)
In such a situation the tests needs to be changed separately from the ones used by master, and when the Gerrit change is merged then those new tests needs to be used by master.

Ok.  Sorry - now I see what you are saying.   in that case, I guess we would have to actually "version" the external resource(s) independently of the version of the fabric.    So let's say that a test on master currently uses "fabric-test-resources/example_chaincode01 version 3" .   You make a change which requires you to modify "example_chaincode01".  So you'd need to push a new version of "fabric-test-resources/example_chaincode01 version 4".  So you push that change and now in your local version of the fabric you modify the test to use "fabric-test-resources/example_chaincode01 version 4".  Things pass locally and now you are ready to submit your change to master.   Shouldn't this work?   Basically the subtle difference is that "fabric-test-resources/example_chaincode01" is versioned independently of the fabric version
this sounds good
maybe it is a bad idea but it would also work if we used multiple subversions: branchversion.currentlyusedsubversion

<@U0PB67X4K> and I were discussing (lamenting, more like;-) the current project structure
we started down the path of one repo to rule them all, and a single build
however, for some aspects of the project, this is starting to become problematic

for instance, the SDKs introduce build dependencies that are likely better handled as independent repositories. The chaincode shim dependency is slightly compromised because while you can go get <http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/etc|github.com/hyperledger/fabric/etc> etc/shim it pulls the entire fabric codebase with it

then, as I was exploring the potential for carving out an independent binary for the CLI (distinct from the peer binary) I found that there is no way to build it without having to build rocksdb (even though there is nothing in the direct dependency tree)
we are already starting down the path of extracting the SDKs (fabric-sdk-py, fabric-sdk-node, etc)

here was <@U0PB67X4K>’s initial proposal: I was thinking we have top level repos like:

1) fabric-crypto
2) fabric-ledger
3) fabric-chaincode-shim
4) fabric-protos
5) fabric-core
6) fabric-orderer
7) fabric-peer
8) fabric-membersrvcs
9) fabric-node-sdk
this will mean that stitching things together will be a bit of work, but I think in the end, will help us greatly by keeping clean interfaces
it will definitely help versioning
Thoughts?
<@U0KPFAZNF> <@U0KN2SSKE> <@U11MANG9G> <@U0MT4CBHB> <@U1AU8DRQR> <@U0XR6J961> <@U0ULK2JPP> <@U0TFEHX8E> ^^

note that IMO, fabric/core is bloated and I don’t think that the concept really holds for all of the bits in there
I know that ledger is basically coming in with a re-boot, so maybe that work could transition from fabric/convergence branch to a separate repo

We should work out the API, move the stuff out of `core/`, etc.
given the strong dependency, should fabric-peer contain core, ledger ? Would core and ledger be used anywhere else ?
We should work out the details. I think the first thing indeed is define the ‘boundary’ of the components and the cross-component API.
I would move the interface to the ECA/TCA out of the core, and expose a layer.

A similar approach from a different perspective might be to ‘query’ using git as part of the process and to compare these to a file. The file will be merged after an approval, and if the `tag` matches what the (voted-over-)file contains the script proceeds to a release.
[Thinking too about how we can avoid needing a YaR… (Yet another Repo) ;-)]
That is, the ‘triggering’ event is when the tag matches the file.
My mental image for these repos is a MIRV warhead. ||: You think you have a handle on it, then it splits into four parts : : |
Yes, the less “linear” & intuitive these are… the more prone we are to errors. I am with you.
We want to automate what we can, while not incurring an insane learning curve or not understanding what’s going on, especially when there is a problem and one is tired…
At same time, multiple platforms, different set-ups, several maintainers, combined code-bases, etc… requires some work/planning/thinking [& some `/self-torturing` ;-)]

While we don't want to add too much overhead and I agree automation and some level of "trust" are fine, we really do need to add some "maturity" to how things get done in this project.   For example, take a look at <https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Release+Process>

<@U0KPFAZNF> you had some concerns about the name of the ‘fabric-node-sdk’ image. I get your point. It really is an image for consuming the sdk and writing applications. Of course, when you think about this going forward, there are some options to consider as to how developers consume fabric. In my fevered imagination, I envisage that developers will work in a typical containerized manner, pulling images to their laptop, running them and exec’ing into them to develop. Hence this really could be considered an SDK container image - for node. Now, the challenge then becomes as we add more chaincode support, then you have combinatorial challenge. Node SDK + Go chaincode, Node + Java chaincode, Java SDK + Java chaincode, Java SDK + Solidity, etc etc etc
I am thinking that we are mostly concerned at this point with v0.6 and that really has just a stable nodeSDK and go chaincode, all of which are in the fabric-sdk-node image.
I suppose we could have fabric—sdk-<sdk lang>-<chaincode lang> available for developers
however, at this point, I wonder if we should just call it fabric-sdk and be done with it for v0.6 and work out something grander for when we have the collection of various sdk and chaincode options

text: we have been thinking about / playing around with using <http://gopkg.in|gopkg.in> in order to version packages where it makes sense.  the most obvious one(s) tend to be the interfaces which "clients" use - e.g. chaincode shim, GRPC APIs, etc.  Chaincode shim has been the biggest trouble maker to date.  Now <http://gopkg.in|gopkg.in> follow a model where you do not break interfaces within a release stream only when doing a major version release.  For example, `go get <http://gopkg.in/mastersingh24/mypackage.v0|gopkg.in/mastersingh24/mypackage.v0>` will be pull the latest branch/tag form `<http://github.com/mastersingh24/mypackage|github.com/mastersingh24/mypackage>` which matches the the form `v0.N.N`.  If we change the interface, you need to bump the version to `v1.N.N`

It would be of interest to me to see how the workflow is improved for the developer who would be the consumer of this proposal.

To some extent the original choice of golang was meant to narrow the choices wrt to module organization, to obviate the issues associated with modularity (see Jigsaw and Java for example).  Thus limiting our options, and not incurring the complexity associated with attempting such a feat, at the cost of development aesthetics (aka it aint pretty, but it's simple).
Golang was predicated on the tenet of limiting your options.
<@U0UKTPMG8> the developer would face less code (easier to understand), the source would be more organized and the components would have a well-defined API
I understand where <@U0UKTPMG8> is coming from, and I would add one more challenge to splitting things up
i would classify it as “the branching problem"
that is, things in one repo are naturally branchable…when you split them up, this becomes more awkward (consider parallel efforts for v0.6 and convergence

<@U1AU8DRQR> At what cost?   I would assert that all of the above can be achieved by reorganizing the code in the fabric repo, (wrt less code, if the developer focuses simply on a module, the same result is attained)
you have to manage the branching with version numbers carefully, and it can be awkward
maybe a heavy reorganization would also do it, no doubt
that said, I am for the split and heres why
if we were talking about purely go modules, the argument to stay as a monolith repo would be stronger, but we arent
node sdk, and java shim are good examples: they are super awkward to be in something considered\ a go-module in certain contexts
We will soon have NEXUS available

having the golang shim be under the fabric project, which has its own vendor, has been a problem

i dont have an opinion on the finer grained parts of the conversation, like splitting out orderer or membersrvc

<@U0KPFAZNF>, <@U0UKTPMG8> I agree. I would argue that the code reorganization within the repo is a critical milestone (which is needed either way).
I think that would be a good start.
I also believe that separating the functionality (even logically) so that the boundaries are clearer… where one can see what services/APIs each component consumes/provides and how… is what we need.

___
Vendoring in go is a good topic, but one that we should resolve regardless too.

I’m more about separating to components/modules (that are more than just directories) where we include whatever is missing (and by that cross the boundaries)… I argue that this is where the bulk of the work lies. The rest should be a lot simpler (and hopefully, will be more convincing/appealing to you <@U0UKTPMG8> and others) once the first step is complete).

Or otherwise, maybe after restructuring the code so nicely, we’ll learn that it’s good enough. But still, it’s a good goal to have, especially when people promote the pluggable architecture. I think that more/better componentization is needed.

attachments.text: We should have a plan for that. Do you think we should do it in small steps or with one big commit?

text: Option 1: All it all in one big/huge commit, with no new tests - but making sure that most of existing tests fail, disabling all lint checks, no sign-offs, tabs, spaces, random licensing info (if at all), and not deploying anything to any CI/build or other online repos, hopefully breaking the preferred/agreed-upon versioning scheme.

Option 2: Gradually, using several iterations, planning, coordinating - also in writing, breaking bigger tasks to sprints, letting everybody know what to expect, sharing the work, added more unit-tests and slowly cross-component integration tests, improving coverage, code-quality and making more people feel-good.
If option 2 does not come across as the preferred way, then I’d beg to differ :wink:
In short: definitely in small steps. Though some parts might be a bit easier than others, so we (can) schedule such changes accordingly.

Maintainers, I would like to know what you think:
Error handling (again). We want to have a solution with multi language support, and some level of hierarchy for errors. (We also want optional call stack support but this is OK.) Now, I see two possible solutions for this:
1) see <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/941/>  It has an error descriptor file (errors.json) with errors which are hierarchical, and consist of a return code plus a reason code. A return code is e.g. the originating module/package/component (e.g. ledger). A reason code is something lower level e.g. Genesis_not_found. These errors have a map of languages + error messages. In JSON this looks like: { "1" : { "1" : { "en" : "Error message" } } }
With this approach a developer instantiates an error using e.g. the following code: errors.Error(LEDGER, GENESIS_NOT_FOUND) where LEDGER and GENESIS... are constants defined in errors.go (framework module) and they are numbers.
The only problem I see with this approach is that we have to maintain the relation between the constants defined in errors.go and the JSON in errors.json. We should be sure that 1) there is an error from the JSON for every constant and a constant for every error from the JSON   2) users do not use wrong pairs, non-existing or ad-hoc defined errors etc...
2) we could have a pre-build source generation process (like in case of protos and make protos) where we would generate a go file containing 1 error struct for every return-reason pair defined by the JSON. (not many files but one with all the structs). e.g. we could use this: <https://github.com/ChimeraCoder/gojson> problem is whether we should commit the generated go file, when to regenerate it, how to do the build etc etc something like in case of protos.

attachments.title: ChimeraCoder/gojson
attachments.text: gojson - Automatically generate Go (golang) struct definitions from example JSON

when do you plan on having facilities in the production flow?
We have these jobs in production flow but without tag based release.. I am missing `git-parameter` in JJB for tag based releases.
long term, im not sure if its needed
i envision the pipeline eventually might be something where an intermediate stage of a -merge job pushes an artifact to nexus, and the -release stage pushes the nexus artifact to the external repo

should we be doing something else?

Back to the previous discussion on releases, here's the dilemma as I see it:

1) It has really been a struggle for people who just want to use the fabric and develop chaincode and applications up to this point.  I've seen that at several hackathons, etc.  The reason is that it is VERY hard to figure out what works with what.  Things like shim changes between v0.5 and v0.6 plus the fact that Go has no versioning in terms of packages have really been a problem.  Also, interface changes make it tough to keep the NodeSDK compatible with release versions of the fabric

2)  We are REALLY struggling to get the V1 work to be the focus for the community as well as get an integrated end to end working version of V1 which we can now fully test and add to.  In order to do this, we need to strip out all of the code from the prior (through v0.6) architecture which really means that the v0.6 branch needs to become that last release of the old architecture

this is where the dind comes in
basically, we tell the peer that the docker daemon address is named ‘docker’ and set the CORE_VM_ENDPOINT accordingly - CORE_VM_ENDPOINT=<http://docker:2375>
to keep them straight, lets differentiate them as dind-true and dind-H
so when the peer spins up a chaincode container, it just asks the daemon in the dind container
right, so I would classify CORE_VM_ENDPOINT as "dind-H"
yes
dind-true is different in that the dockerd runs inside the docker container, and actually nests the underlying containers under itself
whereas dind-H simply fires up containers at the same level as itself
oh, misunderstood
then no
you want true I believe where the containers run inside the dind container
russian dolls
ideally, yes....there are a few issues we need to work through though

i think architecturally, dind-true makes the most sense

but from a practical perspective, its not super mature yet
keeps things tidier
this is true

anyway, where I am going with this is: I think I can get dind-H in place trivially
dind-true might take a bit more work/vetting

i do hope, for a later phase, to move to alpine for the baseimage anyway, which might make things easier to incorporate dind-true at that time
does that sound like an acceptable plan?

i think we are no worse for the wear....we essentially let the UTs drive dockerd on the host today by running them natively...if we then push the UTs into a dind-H container, they are still just driving containers on the host all the same
this is more of an important concept for the peer itself IMO...would be nice to namespace scope the chaincode containers under the peer

if we name the UT container, then docker networking should let any child containers communicate back to any endpoint on the UT container

im not for or against the idea, but I will note that the "-snapshot" that we currently label them with is sufficient in regards to the "unstable" nature, IMO

I don’t think this is a bad idea. Generated (only) by the CI - with a ‘naming scheme’ which allows us to pull the exact built image and test locally… will allow everyone to reuse it. “-snapshot” is fine. We’ll have the version/hash as part of the build, etc. Sounds good to me.

for instance, the fact that we label -snapshot-$sha means we will be adding a lot more artifacts to dockerhub than we would in the more traditional undecorated "-snapshot" label scenario

for example: does SDK want a stable coordinate, a stable release, a coupled version, or just "whatever"

so it doesn’t get picked up by mistake
so, I’d like to talk about docs
currently, the “latest” docs are out of synch
<https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2127/>
<@U0ULK2JPP>  made the comment that rather than update the docs he would just add a comment in the commit on how to use the revised chaincode api
this is a problem IMO
we should be requiring documentation changes with API changes in the same commit
we can clean up the grammar and so forth after the fact, but if we want to have people using the code, then we need to have docs that they can trust
also too, the unit test coverage is slipping and that needs to be addressed
I think that there is talk of cutting a release in the next week or so that captures the skeleton end-2-end operations
if that is the case, then the tests and the docs need to be up to date
they don’t need to be pretty, but the devs that made the changes are the ones that need to review the docs and change as required
<@U0PB67X4K> what you describe above is probably better suited to a jenkins pipeline than dockerhub
e.g. merge kicks off build, build produces artifact, artifact triggers [fabric-unit-tests, sdk-unit-tests], etc
we dont necessarily need that artifact to be pushed to a public namespace, and there is a good reason not to
<@U0KPFAZNF>  - cool.  that's why I tagged you - keep me in line  :wink:
sounds like what I was looking for
When do we want to release a ‘cut’ ?
Off `master` that is?
I could see pushing to an alternate namespace for the unstable builds
[Thanks for the heads-up. It’s good to know/plan for it]
<@U0KM61BCP> the general problem I have with the “non pipeline, push to a namespace” model is often too decoupled…it lacks precision
for instance, if we push everything to “-nightly”, its not precise, its not repeatable
what you described - merge triggers build/publish makes sense to me - isn’t that what we do for a release?
the decoupling to the repo is the problem, i think
yes, but a release is different because its generally a precise coordinate
v0.6.1-preview is precise
-snapshot is not
snapshot-<change_id> would be :wink:
no but it is no different than a local build… I think that the point is to make images available for testing and for advanced development
so you end up with this problem where you either need to create precise coordinates and communicate them to the consumers, or not use precise coordinates and risk non deterministic behavor
I can see then use of another namespace with clarity that this is UNSTABLE
Greg: what’s the problem with `precise coordinates`? (the frequency?)
all I am really saying is there are flows we can exploit that are precise and solve the communication problem that dont involve a tagged artifact in the namespace
well, I suppose we could host our own registry
<@U11MANG9G> ultimately we need precision, the problem is how to communicate that to the consumer
all I am saying is that a pipeline model was kind of designed exactly for this
one jobs output is the input to one or more other jobs
its both precise and communicated
I suppose we could do a daily build
Yes, that’s why I am asking. We need the precise/deterministic/reproducible/...
<@U0KM61BCP>, <@U0KPFAZNF> Yes, with a date.
(or a date+ checkin!)
in the true CI sense, it should be every merge
in the ideal, every commit goes through the pipeline, builds, checks, and possibly, deployment
this is what I was suggesting, but maybe i am misreading you — I thought you were opposed to that?
With post-build deploy.
(Writing at the same time). Yes.
no no, not opposed to that at all…just unsure that pushing each build to dockerhub makes sense
I am fully in favor of each merge going through a pipeline
Pushing each build to our own repo (/published directory/registry). Maybe pushing daily to dockethub or even weekly.
ok, so we have the pipeline… the question is how and how frequently we publish images
Yup
I’ve been reading a good book on this subject, let me find it
(he doesn’t sleep, I am convinced)
(not even on a Friday afternoon. 0-siestas-policy !)

"Continuous Delivery: Reliable Software Releases through Build, Test, and Deployment Automation (Adobe Reader) (Addison-Wesley Signature Series (Fowler))" by Jez Humble, David Farley
<http://amzn.to/2fkrWfd>
anyway, one of the things I found interesting was the notion that you stay away from the notion of deciding a “release"
basically, any commit is a potential release
if it can get through your testing framework, it goes out
well that's the way it is supposed to be
not sure we are ready for that though :wink:
far from it actually
code wise
heh
right…but we should strive for it I think
anyway, long story short, I am not against a fine grained pipeline
all I am saying is, a loosely coupled one might be fragile
yep.  but of course you have the naysayers who will say that this just leads to people wasting time fixing CI builds  :wink:
to which I respond - well if you wrote well-tested code this would not be an issue  :wink:
so if the pipeline was such that the SDK just builds whenever the “-unstable” tag moves, thats not a tight integration
`well if you wrote well-tested code this would not be an issue  :` AMEN !
id rather see it so it walks 1:1 with the artifacts, thus precision
so, yes, I agree on that point about about deciding post facto which build is the release
I would like us to get there
Alright, so putting my good ol’ banker hat for a second.
ultimately I think we are all in agreement, its just a matter of semantics
Where a release to ‘production’ is a big thing.
They usually have a candidate that goes through an extreme set of tests.
the “pipeline” could use dockerhub as an intermediate stage
but all I am saying is, its not strictly necessary
So it is flagged as “ready for deployment” way down the line...
jenkins pipeline and/or nexus could serve us well there
They usually don’t decide in advance what would be a release until after it is built, tested, and in many cases goes through a “staging” environment.
So bottom line, I agree with not declaring in advance what’s a release.
<@U11MANG9G> yes, the stuff ive been reading is basically that, except pushing to “production” is a regular thing (multiple times a day) rather than a red-flag event
but it has to pass through that gauntlet
It has to!
our gauntlet is way too weak right now
Yup, and we don’t have a staging environment (where you run “the full risk” against that candidate for example)
whats also interesting here though is the general notion of “build promotion” can have multiple stages
right!
Not enough test coverage, yada yada yada.
so, there could be [dev, qa, prod]
any developer can stand up a dev stage on their laptop, but qa|prod stages are the output of the CI/CD system
We had `dev`, `qa` (=test), `staging`, `prod`
anyway, we are getting ahead of ourselves…all I was concerned about here is just the proliferation of loosely coupled artifacts to dockerhub
You can load a system in 2 commands in your terminal, just stating against what binaries you want to execute.
and to be clear, I am not saying “-2” to even that, I am just saying,  I think we can do better

on the release thing, it's not only a function of the build working, etc, we need to get into a cadence where we target requirements from JIRA  - meaning a release should be made up of a meaningful set of requirements
that way we can actually ensure that we have an idea of what the heck the thing we put out is actually supposed to accomplish  :wink:
yeah, I think the CD thing is a better model for, say, an enterprise deployment of a service than it is for “shrink wrapped software"
which fabric is closer to the latter
but that said, the tight coupling of a build artifact to a test pipeline is a good one, I think
even if the goal isnt for CD-style release

yep.   not saying we can't put stuff out incrementally, but when it comes to a major release with big ticket items, you want to have a meaningful set of well tested and documented features which make sense to put out
It comes down to writing down meaningful requirements, wiring well tested code and having an automated build and test pipeline
then anything is possible  :wink:
agreed
and in case anyone is not familiar, I was basically thinking something along the lines of; <https://github.com/jenkinsci/pipeline-plugin/blob/master/TUTORIAL.md>

Note: Yes, certificates (aka “signed” certificates) are formatted according to a standard, but they are considered as “clear-text”.
you mean, encoded
(yes, I used ‘formatted’ to avoid confusion with ‘encoded’ that may come across as coded/encrypted).

We might not treat them as fully available pubic information (as they may contain attributes that say a lot), such as one’s Organizational Unit… say, if I have a list of ALL of IBM’s employees, then I would have been able to build the full directory structure.
But on an individual basis, we do not treat a certificate as a “confidential”/encrypted piece of data.

___
There is some cryptographic value in the EnrollmentID string though (esp. in v0.5 and the v0.6 branches), so that should not be considered as “completely public”… but certificates are “up for grabs” :wink:

This is probably a well known issue, but was interesting as I ran into this  first time when dealing with <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2761/>.
```CR 1 - introduces change that will break CR 2 - passes CI and is merged
CR 2 - was not based off CR1. - so passes CI and is merged
After merge of CR2, subsequent CRs will fail CI```

This can only happen if CI runs before merge .. is this assumption correct <@U11HH3P7Y> <@U0UHG4VP1> <@U0KM61BCP> ?
If true, some of the fears that a CR was merged without waiting for CI to V+1 is likely baseless. It could just be dependencies slipping in.

Wait, `PR1`'s parent hash is `master`, and after `PR1` is applied to `master`, it becomes `master'` and PR2 needs a rebase, because its parent hash is still `master` and after a rebase it won't pass CI
if CR2 is rebased, yes… everything will be fine and CI will catch the failure. but if its not, and there are no conflicts, gerritt will signal it can be merged but CI will run BEFORE its merged
<@U0ULK2JPP>: <@U0ZJZBJLF> : we could enable another merge method but it would mean every pending change would need rebased after every commit.

<@U13TWBRBL> done - Btw: at some point we will have to reintroduce some header of sorts. I was thinking ASN.1 marshalling of an integer (that describes the type of identity, 1 for x.509, 2 for idemix etc...) followed by a byte array containing the serialized identity (currently, x.509 will use PEM encoding)
do we agree on this <@U13TWBRBL> <@U0PB67X4K> ?
<@U26T99AQ4> that’s reasonable, until idemix is introduced, assuming the certs are always sent in PEM format I think is sufficient since that seems to be the most prevalent way to exchange certs
will idemix introduce a new kind of cert format?
or encoding rule?
that is of course fine. At the same time, introducing this marshalled int (of with value 1) in front of the PEM byte array is something we can already to today, right?
and yes, idemix will have entirely different structures
so it'll have to be marshalled/unmarshalled in a different way
so for now I'd say we can marshal a "1" integer followed by the PEM encoding of the cert
and if/when idemix is introduced, they'll marhsal a "2" integer followed by their own structures
makes sense?
makes sense. i guess it’s better to introduce this before v1.0 goes out...
why not just use a protobuf struct?
...even if idemix does not come in during this time frame
right, there’s that question too, it’d be much easier to use protobuf than playing with ASN1 encoding

text: <@U0ULK2JPP> yeah, that is curious
oh wait, I know what that is
we don't currently run the orderer as part of the unit-tests
the unit-tests use unit-test/docker-compose.yml
whereas this CR is adding a test/docker-compose.yaml...it isnt consumed by any code
its just there for human convenience
there is a valid argument that somehow some of the orderer/peer compositions could be shared
but I think we would need to do this carefully, there are subtle differences
like, for instance, the ./test/docker-compose purposesly surfaces the peer as localhost ports
this is useful for substituting "docker run --it hyperledger/fabric-peer" for places that used to run "peer node start" natively
but it might not be so convenient for UTs which presumably should avoid potential port conflicts

<@U11MANG9G> <@U0PB67X4K> <@U0KN2SSKE> <@U1BC5A0F9> <@U0ZR63HLK> can we get <@U26T99AQ4>'s <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3293> reviewed and merged? the SDK are dependent on this to catch up to the latest fabric. the SDK has been broken for a while because of the ASN.1 based serialization that the SDK teams have been advocating to be removed, which this changeset replaces.
3293 looks good

Hi, I would like to point out that we are moving from a deterministic serialization mechanism (ASN.1), standard in crypto, to a non-deterministic serialization mechanism (protobuf), at least google does not guarantees deterministic serialization. This might cause problems later. It is better to have this in mind :slightly_smiling_face:
yeah - I had also offered just doing prefixing things with a byte to determine the type as well
BTW - we are serializing and signing protobufs in other areas as well  :wink:
I hope we are doing that having in mind this serialization issue
most of all serialization in `fabric/core` (I wish I can confidently say ALL) happens in `protos/utils`
good to  keep it that way … in general, all marshal/unmarshal under `protos` package where *.proto reside

<@U0ZR63HLK> yes Gari has brought this up as well before but at least as far as the proposal/transaction processing cycles are concerned this is not a problem, as the bytes are generated by the SDK and signed then they are verified as-is throughout the process without being unmarshalled and marshalled again which would have hit the non-deterministic serialization issue. as far as I’m aware, that’s all we need to care about

2017 is approaching. Is it needed to change the year in the license? (in the file headers)
Probably to update to 2016-17. Let me check with legal.
likely only for new files
I would remove years entirely. They only generate confusion. This is not legal advice, but my experience with that exact issue on several projects
If you keep years, you can't just update the year. You need a list, 2016-2017 for instance. Then you end up with 2016-2017,2019-2021 if a file is untouched for a while.
It's messy, brittle, and doesn't give you any information.
<@U0ZJZBJLF>: <@U11MANG9G> <@U0PB67X4K>
for new files, use 2017... no need to go back and edit all of the headers.

text: here are some options I am exploring
1) perhaps there is a newer glibc for ubuntu and I just need to apt-get upgrade and be done
2) ubuntu has some support for musl, not sure how easy it will be to get go/busybox to link with it
3) switch bases for runtime (e.g. alpine)
(3) does have the advantage that it will be easy to build a micro-jre container (thinking chaintool and the java chaincode)
but the disadvantage is I would be leaving P/Z out in the cold
(the workaround for them is they could use standard ubuntu until someone optimizes for size)
so not like they wouldnt work, they just wouldnt be optimized containers
so, there is an update for that package
ill try getting baseimage updated and see if that fixes it (for option (1))
<@U0KM61BCP> as a rule of thumb, perhaps we want to take a hit and "apt-get upgrade" baseimage during the build?
not sure this will address this particular problem, but just thinking about general CVE type things
on one hand, the notion of a non-deterministic operation bothers me a little...on the other, the fact that we are based on an LTS image somewhat mitigates the negative aspects of non-determinism

you may already know this, but a while back I templatized the peer's processing of the Dockerfile
for instance, in core/yaml, you see these: FROM hyperledger/fabric-ccenv:$(ARCH)-$(PROJECT_VERSION)
so the peer will substitute the correct parameters at runtime to match the ARCH/VER that its running on
this was done in prep for CR4943, but has just been more or less irrelevant until now

For the hackfest or otherwise.

For those that are truly interested in running the bccsp/pkcs11 unit tests using the softhsm2 utility, they can either run `make unit-test` with the TEST_PKGS env variable set to the desired pkcs11 tests, or run a testenv container and perform specific pkcs11 tests there.

I tested <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/4929/2> on z and it looks like it addresses the case where folks aren't interested in using the softhsm2 utility while running unit tests outside of the testenv docker container.
<@U0YK3KKCY> Yes, ok. So we can have the pkcs11 tests not specified in the TEST_PKGS by default, so that `make unit-test` ignore them. I agree.

Now, the main question (left) is whether we would like to support also the `go test ./…` command out of the box… or are we happy to limit users to use our make. Again, looking for opinions, mostly. [*Sorry for the editing, just having a strong coffee*]
[Happy to do the “leg work” and fix it, either way]
I think we should be happy scoping this within the testenv docker container (make).  The audience interested in pkcs11 specifically, in my opinion, is a very low number at this point.

re: TEST_PKGS, I was suggesting this could be used for folks specifically interested in running just pkcs11 tests (by-passing all other tests).

OK, while I usually don’t like doing that, I can also put my cowboy hat and suggest a “hack” at times…
So I while `go` lets us have the `-short` flag that executes only the tests that check the `Short()` predicate… unfortunately, it’s not on by default… so that would not help here. However, instead:

We can also set/check for a temporary ENV VAR, `FABRIC_TEST_PKCS11` or `FABRIC_TEST_EXTRA_PACKAGES` or something along these lines (*highlighting as naming variables is always an interesting topic!* :slightly_smiling_face: )...
So that we test ONLY if these env variables are set. So that the regular/naive/trivial/expected `go test ./…` would still skip these.
Thoughts?
....thinking...
CR-4929 by default, would by-pass pkcs11 unit tests within a "native" test (go test ./...) environment.
If folks would like to test pkcs11 outside of the testenv docker image, they would have to install softhsm2 on their local machine.
Yes, that’s how we got “here” :wink:
ha

I had expressed some reservations about creating a formal release at this stage...my experience with the state of the code coupled with my experience last time we released artifacts to dockerhub make me recommend that we hold off a bit
I tend to share those reservations
though I also understand and appreciate the desire to have a smooth and productive hackfest
so we were trying to strategize on how to best do that
here is a summary of my sentiment: last go round we pushed images out to dockerhub before we were really ready to offer a dockerhub model
as a result, lots of users were confused, and who knows how many simply gave up without asking for help
i wanted to avoid that happening again
<@U0KM61BCP>  that one misses a couple of steps that greg just pinged me — i’ll update the page
thanks
we are getting closer to actually offering a dockerhub model (e.g. FAB-678) and I expect to rapidly converge on that in the next few weeks
but its not quite there yet
couple that to the fact that, in my experience the last few weeks, the code base itself is in pretty fragile state
therefore, my vote would be to hold off on any kind of formal release
that said, I will respect the consensus of all the maintainers
to the point of hackfest experience, the thought was perhaps an alternate dockerhub ns could be used

one that should ideally make it both easy for hackfest attendees to have a smooth experience and to also convey to the broader community that this is something specific to the hackfest, not a general release (pre-alpha or not)

we currently have docker images and document to walk users through step by step;  it is probably not inline with fab-678, but solid for developers to deploy chaincodes and write apps using SDK (limited APIs now)
of course things will continue to improve as we move into beta next month
but I think it is important that we give app developers something to work with now
I understand, just from my experience fielding all the questions about things like "baseimage:latest", most users tend to "shoot" (ala "docker run") first and ask questions later
<@U0KN2SSKE> right so I think that the idea of publishing this (manually) to sfhackfest22017 is the right decision - <@U11HH3P7Y> is working on setting that up, I believe
we currently dont really act like a typical docker container experience
after FAB-678, we will
and again, its just my vote: i dont think we are ready, but I wont obstruct consensus
if this is what we all agree we want, i will help make it happen
we can package it as sfhackfest22017 and make that available, but we do need to decide on criteria for alpha — if we agree fab-678 then we’ll focus on that
i am ok with pushing for fab-678 to alpha

i think minimally FAB-678, yes...my experience using the general suite the last few weeks did not give me the impression we were the epitome of stability either...that would also be pre-req...but I recognize that its a rapidly moving target and that is likely contributing to the stability, perceived or otherwise
currently I run a series of duct-tape and chewing gum patches on top of the upstream tree just to hobble things together, and any time I move HEAD things generally break
and then getting those fixes, breaks other things, etc
heh
its a frustrating game of whack-a-mole
if we can nail ABI, stablity, and FAB-678, then I would feel confident in making the cut
yes, the last few weeks were very rough — things just stable in the last few days (ABI, especially protos are fixed now)
thats good, that will help
sort of in the ABI space, FAB-678 will change the deployment CodePackage spec, FYI, though I anticipate it will be predominantly backwards compatible
basically, I anticipate the CodePackage will look exactly as it does today...the difference is clients/SDKs may omit the Dockerfile
ideally, we can get them all fixed so they _dont_ include it, just because I think it would lead to confusion
but in the end, we can just safely ignore any Dockerfiles included if there are stragglers
I suppose we have some ABI flexibility coming out of alpha though
this is more of a v1.0 criteria
we certain do as requirements/feedback from users
